metadata.description: DSM-5 Diagnostic Criteria Bank - Fully Compliant with DSM-5 Standards

MDD.clinical_notes: At least 5 symptoms present during the same 2-week period, representing a change from previous functioning. At least one symptom must be either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure.

criteria.text: Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day
criteria.note: Must have either A1 or A2

criteria.text: Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day
criteria.note: Must have either A1 or A2

criteria.text: Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day
Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day
Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day (observable by others)
Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day
Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day
Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day
Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or specific plan for committing suicide

exclusion_criteria: Not attributable to physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition
Not better explained by schizophrenia spectrum or other psychotic disorders
No history of manic or hypomanic episode

severity_levels.mild: Few, if any, symptoms in excess of those required to make the diagnosis, and symptoms result in minor impairment in occupational functioning or usual social activities or relationships
severity_levels.moderate: Symptoms or functional impairment between 'mild' and 'severe'
severity_levels.severe: Number of symptoms substantially in excess of that required to make the diagnosis, and symptoms seriously interfere with occupational functioning or usual social activities or relationships

GAD.duration_requirement: At least 6 months, more days than not
GAD.clinical_notes: Excessive anxiety and worry (Criterion A) must be present, along with difficulty controlling worry (Criterion B), and at least 3 of 6 associated symptoms (Criterion C).

criteria.text: Excessive anxiety and worry (apprehensive expectation), occurring more days than not for at least 6 months, about a number of events or activities
The individual finds it difficult to control the worry
Restlessness or feeling keyed up or on edge
criteria.note: Need 3 of 6 from C1-C6

criteria.text: Being easily fatigued
criteria.note: Need 3 of 6 from C1-C6

criteria.text: Difficulty concentrating or mind going blank
criteria.note: Need 3 of 6 from C1-C6

criteria.text: Irritability
criteria.note: Need 3 of 6 from C1-C6

criteria.text: Muscle tension
criteria.note: Need 3 of 6 from C1-C6

criteria.text: Sleep disturbance (difficulty falling or staying asleep, or restless, unsatisfying sleep)
criteria.note: Need 3 of 6 from C1-C6

exclusion_criteria: Not attributable to physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition
Not better explained by another mental disorder

PANIC.duration_requirement: At least 1 month of persistent concern or worry about additional attacks or maladaptive change in behavior
PANIC.clinical_notes: Recurrent unexpected panic attacks required. A panic attack is defined as an abrupt surge of intense fear/discomfort that reaches a peak within minutes, with 4+ of 13 symptoms. Diagnosis requires Criterion A (recurrent attacks) AND Criterion B (persistent concern/worry for at least 1 month).

criteria.text: Recurrent unexpected panic attacks
criteria.note: A panic attack = abrupt surge of intense fear/discomfort peaking within minutes with 4+ symptoms from B1-B13

criteria.text: At least one of the attacks has been followed by 1 month (or more) of one or both: persistent concern about additional panic attacks or their consequences, OR significant maladaptive change in behavior related to the attacks

panic_attack_symptoms.text: Palpitations, pounding heart, or accelerated heart rate
Sensations of shortness of breath or smothering
Feeling dizzy, unsteady, light-headed, or faint
Derealization (feelings of unreality) or depersonalization (being detached from oneself)
Fear of losing control or 'going crazy'

exclusion_criteria: Not attributable to physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition
Not better explained by another mental disorder

severity_levels.severe: Severe worry and marked life interference

SUBSTANCE_USE.clinical_notes: A problematic pattern of substance use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress, manifested by at least 2 of 11 criteria occurring within a 12-month period.

criteria.text: Substance is often taken in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended
There is a persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control substance use
A great deal of time is spent in activities necessary to obtain the substance, use the substance, or recover from its effects
Craving, or a strong desire or urge to use the substance
Recurrent substance use resulting in a failure to fulfill major role obligations at work, school, or home
Continued substance use despite having persistent or recurrent social or interpersonal problems caused or exacerbated by the effects of the substance
Important social, occupational, or recreational activities are given up or reduced because of substance use
Recurrent substance use in situations in which it is physically hazardous
Substance use is continued despite knowledge of having a persistent or recurrent physical or psychological problem that is likely to have been caused or exacerbated by the substance

Tolerance, as defined by either: (a) a need for markedly increased amounts of the substance to achieve intoxication or desired effect, or (b) a markedly diminished effect with continued use of the same amount

Withdrawal, as manifested by either: (a) the characteristic withdrawal syndrome for the substance, or (b) the substance (or a closely related substance) is taken to relieve or avoid withdrawal symptoms

ADHD.duration_requirement: Symptoms present for at least 6 months
ADHD.clinical_notes: Requires 6+ symptoms from either inattention OR hyperactivity-impulsivity (or both for Combined presentation). For individuals 17+ years, at least 5 symptoms are required. Symptoms must be present before age 12, present in two or more settings, and interfere with functioning.

criteria.text: Often fails to give close attention to details or makes careless mistakes in schoolwork, at work, or during other activities
criteria.note: Need 6+ from inattention cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Often has difficulty sustaining attention in tasks or play activities
criteria.note: Need 6+ from inattention cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Often does not seem to listen when spoken to directly
criteria.note: Need 6+ from inattention cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Often does not follow through on instructions and fails to finish schoolwork, chores, or duties in the workplace
criteria.note: Need 6+ from inattention cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Often has difficulty organizing tasks and activities
criteria.note: Need 6+ from inattention cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Often avoids, dislikes, or is reluctant to engage in tasks that require sustained mental effort
criteria.note: Need 6+ from inattention cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Often loses things necessary for tasks or activities
criteria.note: Need 6+ from inattention cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Is often easily distracted by extraneous stimuli
criteria.note: Need 6+ from inattention cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Is often forgetful in daily activities
criteria.note: Need 6+ from inattention cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Often fidgets with or taps hands or feet or squirms in seat
criteria.note: Need 6+ from H-I cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Often leaves seat in situations when remaining seated is expected
criteria.note: Need 6+ from H-I cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Often runs about or climbs in situations where it is inappropriate (in adolescents or adults, may be limited to feeling restless)
criteria.note: Need 6+ from H-I cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Often unable to play or engage in leisure activities quietly
criteria.note: Need 6+ from H-I cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Is often 'on the go,' acting as if 'driven by a motor'
criteria.note: Need 6+ from H-I cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Often talks excessively
criteria.note: Need 6+ from H-I cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Often blurts out an answer before a question has been completed
criteria.note: Need 6+ from H-I cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Often has difficulty waiting his or her turn
criteria.note: Need 6+ from H-I cluster (5+ for age 17+)

criteria.text: Often interrupts or intrudes on others
criteria.note: Need 6+ from H-I cluster (5+ for age 17+)

presentations.combined: If both Criterion A1 (inattention) and Criterion A2 (hyperactivity-impulsivity) are met for the past 6 months
presentations.predominantly_inattentive: If Criterion A1 (inattention) is met but Criterion A2 (hyperactivity-impulsivity) is not met for the past 6 months
presentations.predominantly_hyperactive_impulsive: If Criterion A2 (hyperactivity-impulsivity) is met and Criterion A1 (inattention) is not met for the past 6 months

additional_requirements: Several inattentive or hyperactive-impulsive symptoms were present prior to age 12 years
Several symptoms are present in two or more settings
Clear evidence that symptoms interfere with functioning
Symptoms do not occur exclusively during course of schizophrenia or another psychotic disorder
Not better explained by another mental disorder

severity_levels.mild: Few, if any, symptoms in excess of those required to make the diagnosis are present, and symptoms result in no more than minor impairments
severity_levels.moderate: Symptoms or functional impairment between 'mild' and 'severe' are present
severity_levels.severe: Many symptoms in excess of those required to make the diagnosis, or several symptoms that are particularly severe, are present, or the symptoms result in marked impairment

ADJUSTMENT.duration_requirement: Symptoms develop within 3 months of onset of stressor(s) and do not persist for more than 6 months after the stressor or its consequences have terminated
ADJUSTMENT.clinical_notes: Development of emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor(s) occurring within 3 months of the onset of the stressor(s).

criteria.text: The development of emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor(s) occurring within 3 months of the onset of the stressor(s)

These symptoms or behaviors are clinically significant, as evidenced by one or both of the following: (1) Marked distress that is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor, taking into account the external context and cultural factors; (2) Significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning
The stress-related disturbance does not meet the criteria for another mental disorder and is not merely an exacerbation of a preexisting mental disorder
The symptoms do not represent normal bereavement
Once the stressor or its consequences have terminated, the symptoms do not persist for more than an additional 6 months

specifiers.with_depressed_mood: Low mood, tearfulness, or feelings of hopelessness are predominant
specifiers.with_anxiety: Nervousness, worry, jitteriness, or separation anxiety is predominant
specifiers.with_mixed_anxiety_and_depressed_mood: A combination of depression and anxiety is predominant
specifiers.with_mixed_disturbance_of_emotions_and_c: Both emotional symptoms and disturbance of conduct are predominant
specifiers.unspecified: For maladaptive reactions that are not classifiable as one of the specific subtypes

BIPOLAR.duration_requirement: At least 1 week (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary)
BIPOLAR.clinical_notes: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased goal-directed activity or energy, lasting at least 1 week. Requires 3 (or 4 if mood is only irritable) of 7 symptoms.

criteria.text: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy, lasting at least 1 week and present most of the day, nearly every day (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary)
Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
criteria.note: Need 3 of 7 (or 4 if mood is only irritable)

criteria.text: Decreased need for sleep (e.g., feels rested after only 3 hours of sleep)
criteria.note: Need 3 of 7 (or 4 if mood is only irritable)

criteria.text: More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking
criteria.note: Need 3 of 7 (or 4 if mood is only irritable)

criteria.text: Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing
criteria.note: Need 3 of 7 (or 4 if mood is only irritable)

criteria.text: Distractibility (i.e., attention too easily drawn to unimportant or irrelevant external stimuli), as reported or observed
criteria.note: Need 3 of 7 (or 4 if mood is only irritable)

criteria.text: Increase in goal-directed activity (either socially, at work or school, or sexually) or psychomotor agitation
criteria.note: Need 3 of 7 (or 4 if mood is only irritable)

criteria.text: Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences (e.g., engaging in unrestrained buying sprees, sexual indiscretions, or foolish business investments)
criteria.note: Need 3 of 7 (or 4 if mood is only irritable)

additional_requirements: The mood disturbance is sufficiently severe to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization to prevent harm to self or others, or there are psychotic features
The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition

severity_levels.moderate: Very significant increase in activity or impairment in judgment
severity_levels.severe: Almost continual supervision required to prevent physical harm to self or others

SOCIAL_ANXIETY.clinical_notes: Marked fear or anxiety about one or more social situations in which the individual is exposed to possible scrutiny by others. All criteria A through G must be met.

criteria.text: Marked fear or anxiety about one or more social situations in which the individual is exposed to possible scrutiny by others. Examples include social interactions, being observed, and performing in front of others
The individual fears that he or she will act in a way or show anxiety symptoms that will be negatively evaluated
The social situations almost always provoke fear or anxiety
The social situations are avoided or endured with intense fear or anxiety
The fear or anxiety is out of proportion to the actual threat posed by the social situation and to the sociocultural context
The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is persistent, typically lasting for 6 months or more
The fear, anxiety, or avoidance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning
The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition
The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder

specifiers.performance_only: If the fear is restricted to speaking or performing in public

severity_levels.mild: Avoidance of or anxiety about 1 feared social situation
severity_levels.moderate: Avoidance of or anxiety about at least 2 but less than majority of social situations
severity_levels.severe: Avoidance of or anxiety about majority of social situations

SPECIFIC_PHOBIA.clinical_notes: Marked fear or anxiety about a specific object or situation. All criteria A through G must be met.

criteria.text: Marked fear or anxiety about a specific object or situation (e.g., flying, heights, animals, receiving an injection, seeing blood)
The phobic object or situation almost always provokes immediate fear or anxiety
The phobic object or situation is actively avoided or endured with intense fear or anxiety
The fear or anxiety is out of proportion to the actual danger posed by the specific object or situation and to the sociocultural context
The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is persistent, typically lasting for 6 months or more
The fear, anxiety, or avoidance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning
The disturbance is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder

specifiers.other: e.g., situations that may lead to choking or vomiting; in children, loud sounds or costumed characters

AGORAPHOBIA.clinical_notes: Marked fear or anxiety about two (or more) of five situations: public transportation, open spaces, enclosed places, standing in line or being in a crowd, or being outside of the home alone.

criteria.text: Marked fear or anxiety about two (or more) of the following five situations
criteria.note: Must have 2+ of the 5 situations below

criteria.text: Using public transportation (e.g., automobiles, buses, trains, ships, planes)
criteria.note: Part of Criterion A - need 2+ of 5

criteria.text: Being in open spaces (e.g., parking lots, marketplaces, bridges)
criteria.note: Part of Criterion A - need 2+ of 5

criteria.text: Being in enclosed places (e.g., shops, theaters, cinemas)
criteria.note: Part of Criterion A - need 2+ of 5

criteria.text: Standing in line or being in a crowd
criteria.note: Part of Criterion A - need 2+ of 5

criteria.text: Being outside of the home alone
criteria.note: Part of Criterion A - need 2+ of 5

criteria.text: The individual fears or avoids these situations because of thoughts that escape might be difficult or help might not be available in the event of developing panic-like symptoms or other incapacitating or embarrassing symptoms
The agoraphobic situations almost always provoke fear or anxiety
The agoraphobic situations are actively avoided, require the presence of a companion, or are endured with intense fear or anxiety
The fear or anxiety is out of proportion to the actual danger posed by the agoraphobic situations and to the sociocultural context
The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is persistent, typically lasting for 6 months or more
The fear, anxiety, or avoidance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning
If another medical condition is present, the fear, anxiety, or avoidance is clearly excessive
The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder

severity_levels.severe: Avoidance of 3 or more agoraphobic situations

PTSD.duration_requirement: Duration of disturbance is more than 1 month
PTSD.clinical_notes: Exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence. Must meet criteria from Criterion B (1+ intrusion symptoms), C (1+ avoidance), D (2+ negative alterations), and E (2+ arousal symptoms).

criteria.text: Exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence in one (or more) of the following ways: directly experiencing, witnessing, learning it occurred to close family/friend, or experiencing repeated or extreme exposure to aversive details

criterion_b_intrusion.requirement: One or more of the following intrusion symptoms

symptoms.text: Recurrent, involuntary, and intrusive distressing memories of the traumatic event(s)
Recurrent distressing dreams in which the content and/or affect of the dream are related to the traumatic event(s)
Dissociative reactions (e.g., flashbacks) in which the individual feels or acts as if the traumatic event(s) were recurring
Intense or prolonged psychological distress at exposure to internal or external cues that symbolize or resemble an aspect of the traumatic event(s)
Marked physiological reactions to internal or external cues that symbolize or resemble an aspect of the traumatic event(s)

criterion_c_avoidance.requirement: Persistent avoidance of stimuli associated with the traumatic event(s), beginning after the traumatic event(s) occurred, as evidenced by one or both

symptoms.text: Avoidance of or efforts to avoid distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings about or closely associated with the traumatic event(s)

Avoidance of or efforts to avoid external reminders (people, places, conversations, activities, objects, situations) that arouse distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings about or closely associated with the traumatic event(s)

criterion_d_negative_alterations.requirement: Negative alterations in cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event(s), beginning or worsening after the traumatic event(s) occurred, as evidenced by two (or more)

symptoms.text: Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event(s) (typically due to dissociative amnesia, not to other factors)
Persistent and exaggerated negative beliefs or expectations about oneself, others, or the world
Persistent, distorted cognitions about the cause or consequences of the traumatic event(s) that lead the individual to blame himself/herself or others
Persistent negative emotional state (e.g., fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame)
Markedly diminished interest or participation in significant activities
Feelings of detachment or estrangement from others
Persistent inability to experience positive emotions (e.g., inability to experience happiness, satisfaction, or loving feelings)

criterion_e_arousal.requirement: Marked alterations in arousal and reactivity associated with the traumatic event(s), beginning or worsening after the traumatic event(s) occurred, as evidenced by two (or more)

symptoms.text: Irritable behavior and angry outbursts (with little or no provocation) typically expressed as verbal or physical aggression toward people or objects
Reckless or self-destructive behavior
Hypervigilance
Exaggerated startle response
Problems with concentration
Sleep disturbance (e.g., difficulty falling or staying asleep or restless sleep)

additional_requirements: Duration of the disturbance (Criteria B, C, D, and E) is more than 1 month
The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning
The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition

specifiers.with_delayed_expression: If full diagnostic criteria are not met until at least 6 months after the event

severity_levels.mild: Few symptoms beyond those required, minor impairment
severity_levels.moderate: Symptoms or functional impairment between 'mild' and 'severe'
severity_levels.severe: Many symptoms beyond those required, severe functional impairment

OCD.duration_requirement: Time-consuming (more than 1 hour per day) or cause clinically significant distress or impairment
OCD.clinical_notes: Presence of obsessions, compulsions, or both. Obsessions and compulsions are defined separately with specific criteria.

criteria.text: Presence of obsessions, compulsions, or both

components.text: Recurrent and persistent thoughts, urges, or images that are experienced, at some time during the disturbance, as intrusive and unwanted, and that in most individuals cause marked anxiety or distress
The individual attempts to ignore or suppress such thoughts, urges, or images, or to neutralize them with some other thought or action (i.e., by performing a compulsion)

Repetitive behaviors (e.g., hand washing, ordering, checking) or mental acts (e.g., praying, counting, repeating words silently) that the individual feels driven to perform in response to an obsession or according to rules that must be applied rigidly

The behaviors or mental acts are aimed at preventing or reducing anxiety or distress, or preventing some dreaded event or situation; however, these behaviors or mental acts are not connected in a realistic way with what they are designed to neutralize or prevent, or are clearly excessive

additional_criteria.text: The obsessions or compulsions are time-consuming (take more than 1 hour per day) or cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning
The obsessive-compulsive symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition
The disturbance is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder

specifiers.with_good_or_fair_insight: The individual recognizes that OCD beliefs are definitely or probably not true
specifiers.with_poor_insight: The individual thinks OCD beliefs are probably true
specifiers.with_absent_insight_delusional: The individual is completely convinced that OCD beliefs are true
specifiers.tic_related: The individual has a current or past history of a tic disorder

severity_levels.mild: Time consumed by symptoms is 1-3 hours per day, or occasional intrusion with mild impairment
severity_levels.moderate: Time consumed is 3-8 hours per day, or frequent intrusion with moderate impairment
severity_levels.severe: Time consumed is greater than 8 hours per day, or near-constant intrusion with severe impairment

ALCOHOL_USE.clinical_notes: A problematic pattern of alcohol use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress, as manifested by at least 2 of 11 criteria, occurring within a 12-month period. Identical structure to general Substance Use Disorder but specific to alcohol.

criteria.text: Alcohol is often taken in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended
There is a persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control alcohol use
A great deal of time is spent in activities necessary to obtain alcohol, use alcohol, or recover from its effects
Craving, or a strong desire or urge to use alcohol
Recurrent alcohol use resulting in a failure to fulfill major role obligations at work, school, or home
Continued alcohol use despite having persistent or recurrent social or interpersonal problems caused or exacerbated by the effects of alcohol
Important social, occupational, or recreational activities are given up or reduced because of alcohol use
Recurrent alcohol use in situations in which it is physically hazardous
Alcohol use is continued despite knowledge of having a persistent or recurrent physical or psychological problem that is likely to have been caused or exacerbated by alcohol

Tolerance, as defined by either: (a) a need for markedly increased amounts of alcohol to achieve intoxication or desired effect, or (b) a markedly diminished effect with continued use of the same amount of alcohol
Withdrawal, as manifested by either: (a) the characteristic withdrawal syndrome for alcohol, or (b) alcohol (or a closely related substance) is taken to relieve or avoid withdrawal symptoms

specifiers.in_early_remission: After full criteria were previously met, none of the criteria have been met for at least 3 months but for less than 12 months (except Criterion A4, craving, may be met)
specifiers.in_sustained_remission: After full criteria were previously met, none of the criteria have been met at any time during a period of 12 months or longer (except Criterion A4, craving, may be met)
specifiers.in_a_controlled_environment: This additional specifier is used if the individual is in an environment where access to alcohol is restricted

EATING_DISORDERS.clinical_notes: This represents Anorexia Nervosa criteria. For comprehensive eating disorders assessment, separate criteria for Bulimia Nervosa and Binge-Eating Disorder should be included.

criteria.text: Restriction of energy intake relative to requirements, leading to a significantly low body weight in the context of age, sex, developmental trajectory, and physical health
Intense fear of gaining weight or of becoming fat, or persistent behavior that interferes with weight gain, even though at a significantly low weight

Disturbance in the way in which one's body weight or shape is experienced, undue influence of body weight or shape on self-evaluation, or persistent lack of recognition of the seriousness of the current low body weight

specifiers.restricting_type: During the last 3 months, the individual has not engaged in recurrent episodes of binge eating or purging behavior (i.e., self-induced vomiting or the misuse of laxatives, diuretics, or enemas)
specifiers.binge_eating_purging_type: During the last 3 months, the individual has engaged in recurrent episodes of binge eating or purging behavior

EATING_DISORDERS.note: For complete eating disorders assessment, also consider Bulimia Nervosa (recurrent binge eating + compensatory behaviors) and Binge-Eating Disorder (recurrent binge eating without compensatory behaviors)

criteria_types_explained.symptom_count: Need X number of symptoms from a list (e.g., 5 of 9 for MDD)
criteria_types_explained.sequential: Must meet all criteria A, B, C, D, etc. in order
criteria_types_explained.hybrid: Combination of required core criteria plus symptom count (e.g., GAD needs A+B+3 of 6)
criteria_types_explained.cluster: Must meet minimum from multiple symptom clusters (e.g., PTSD needs 1+ from B, 1+ from C, 2+ from D, 2+ from E)
